ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Coates cares about making you into a stronger, more critical thinker and writer.

I developed a new appreciation for film and a broader appreciation for dance. I became more aware of the various components, choreographically and compositionally, in various pieces and was able to identify and explain these. Additionally, I grew in my ability to describe and analyze dance and film techniques in my writing.
I learned how to talk and write about art and view the world from an artist's perspective. I also learned about dance and film through the years and how they have changed with society.

You will learn more about the impact of different filming techniques and how they contribute to the overall message of the film itself. Additionally, you will also gain deeper insight about the significance of movement in dance and how it can help construct meaning throughout a choreography.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed the variety of films we watched with our discussions, as well as learning the history of dance on film before delving into the various components of dance on film and how they impact the art form. We watched things from Beyonc videos to old Hollywood musicals to more modern experimental films. I will say that some films were more interesting and had more to unpack than others, especially when it came to experimental pieces. I think the reflections required for each class were very helpful not only in allowing me to grow as a writer and become more familiar with describing pieces but also to organize my thoughts and digest the films and readings before discussion sections. Some of the readings were very interesting and pertinent to our study, others seemed a little dry and repetitive. Overall, though, this class was interesting and moved at a great pace.
The weekly discussion posts give students valuable practice in both viewing and writing. Also, the small, very involved class made discussions very insightful and informative.

This course was very fun and engaging. We did simple choreographic exercises at the beginning of every class! The first part of the course is more about the history of dance on film and it's more challenging than the final half. The final half was more fun, you get to learn about film techniques and watch films for homework. You will have to talk a lot in the class and give out your opinion because it is a small seminar, which was difficult for me.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Coates keeps her students engaged through interesting class discussions and viewings that make class exciting! I always looked forward to our class zooms.

I loved the movement work we did each class. It was a nice break from sitting all day in front of my computer. I thought our discussion section, in part because of its small size, lended very well towards virtual learning as we all were able to speak, ask questions, and respond to one another.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this course to another student! It is fun, interesting, and valuable.

Yes, I would recommend this course to students interested in dance or film and those open to broadening their understanding and appreciation of this art form. The content is very interesting and well-presented, but it does require the students' engagement and interest as well.

I would recommend this course to anyone with an interest in either dance or film. It teaches you a lot about the history of these topics, as well as how to make a film of your own. You also learn a lot about composition and movement, which makes you view film and art in a new way.
I would recommend it! The readings are difficult because it is weird to read about dance and film theory, but it is a fun way to get a writing distribution credit.
Yes! I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone that's interested in learning more about film or dance.
